subject: Design
title: Punch Cards: Programming Without a Screen
description: One-minute skill: Punch Cards: Programming Without a Screen.

hook.text: In the 1960s, programmers didn't type code. They punched holes in stiff paper cards.

buildup.text: Each card held one line of instructions. A single program could be a stack of hundreds.

discovery.text: Drop the stack and your cards scatter. One wrong order and the program crashes.

twist.text: Programmers drew diagonal lines on card edges so they could re-sort a dropped deck.

climax.text: Punch cards forced a brutal discipline: think before you punch, because fixing errors took hours.

punchline.text: The first user interface was a hole in a piece of paper.

quiz.question: Why did programmers draw diagonal lines on punch card stacks?
